etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French (chien) terrier ‘earth (dog)’, from medieval Latin terrarius, from Latin terra ‘earth’

definitions: a small dog of a breed originally used for turning out foxes and other burrowing animals from their lairs.
shortDefinitions: small dog of breed originally used for turning out foxes and other burrowing animals from their lairs

definitions: used in similes to emphasize tenacity or eagerness

examples.text: she would fight like a terrier for every penny

shortDefinitions: used in similes to emphasize tenacity or eagerness

etymologies: late 15th century: from Old French terrier, from medieval Latin terrarius (liber) ‘(book) of land’, from Latin terra ‘earth’

definitions: a register of the lands belonging to a landowner, originally including a list of tenants, their holdings, and the rents paid, later consisting of a description of the acreage and boundaries of the property.
shortDefinitions: register of lands belonging to landowner, originally including list of tenants

definitions: an inventory of property or goods.
